questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a neck mass and weight loss. He first noticed the growing mass 2 months ago. The mass is not painful. He also has decreased appetite and intermittent abdominal pain. He has lost 10 kg (22 lb) of weight over the past 3 months. Sometimes, he wakes up in the morning drenched in sweat. He takes daily over-the-counter multivitamins. He appears pale. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a painless, golf ball-sized mass in the anterior triangle of the neck. A biopsy shows large cells with a bilobed nucleus that are CD15 and CD30 positive. Serum studies show a calcium concentration of 14.5 mg/dL and a parathyroid hormone concentration of 4 pg/mL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's serum findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoblastic metastases can occur in a patient with lymphoma. However, they are not associated with hypercalcemia because an osteoblastic process does not result in a positive calcium balance. Moreover, this patient does not have back or bone pain to suggest bone involvement. Osteoblastic bone metastases are commonly seen in patients with prostate cancer and small cell lung cancer.

B) CORRECT:

Ectopic vitamin D production as a result of increased 1α-hydroxylase activity in proliferating lymphoid tissue is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in patients with Hodgkin lymphoma. Elevated levels of active vitamin D induce intestinal resorption and renal reabsorption of calcium, resulting in hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia, in turn, suppresses the release of PTH.

This mechanism of vitamin D-induced hypercalcemia is also seen in chronic granulomatous diseases, such as sarcoidosis and tuberculosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by tumor cells is the underlying mechanism of humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM), a paraneoplastic syndrome that causes up to 80% of cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy. HHM would result in low levels of PTH since PTHrP is not detected by laboratory assays for PTH and hypercalcemia suppresses PTH production. However, HHM is most often associated with squamous cell carcinomas (lung, head, and neck) and renal, bladder, breast, or ovarian carcinomas. Hypercalcemia in individuals with Hodgkin lymphoma can, in very rare cases, be caused by PTHrP production, but the vast majority of such cases are due to a different pathomechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient takes a daily multivitamin. A vitamin D overdose would result in hypercalcemia and decreased levels of PTH due to negative feedback from increased calcium levels (secondary hypoparathyroidism). However, a different mechanism is much more likely to be the cause of hypercalcemia in a patient with a suspected lymphoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteolytic metastases, which can occur in a patient with advanced lymphoma, can cause hypercalcemia (due to the release of proteins that stimulate bone resorption, e.g., IL-6), and secondary hypoparathyroidism. However, this patient does not have back or long bone pain to suggest bone involvement. Osteolytic bone metastases are most commonly seen in patients with multiple myeloma as well as solid tumors (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, breast cancer).
questions.hint: This patient's B symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fever, night sweats), lymphadenopathy, biopsy findings of CD15/CD30 antigens and large cells with a bilobed nucleus (Reed-Sternberg cells) indicate that the patient has Hodgkin lymphoma, which typically causes hypercalcemia by a paraneoplastic mechanism.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurring fever and night sweats. The fevers persist for 7 to 10 days and then subside completely for about a week before returning again. During the past 6 months, has had a 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss and has also noticed painless lumps on his neck that have gradually increased in size. Two years ago, he had a severe sore throat and fever, which was diagnosed as infectious mononucleosis. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He does not drink alcohol. His job involves monthly international travel to Asia and Africa. He takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows enlarged, nontender, fixed cervical lymph nodes on each side of the neck. A photomicrograph from a biopsy of a cervical lymph node is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: IgG and IgM antibodies against a viral capsid antigen
Acid fast bacilli in the sputum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A proliferation of monomorphic lymphocytic cells is a characteristic feature of some non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs), in contrast to the heterogeneous morphology of classic Hodgkin lymphoma. NHLs can cause lymphadenopathy and B symptoms but histopathology is unlikely to show Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, NHLs often cause extranodal disease, most commonly involving the gastrointestinal tract, skin, thyroid, and CNS, but the patient has no complaints relating to any of these organs.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, i.e., infectious mononucleosis (IM), would result in the presence of both IgG and IgM antibodies against the EBV-associated viral capsid antigen (VCA). Because of this patient's past IM, he would test positive for IgG anti-VCA antibodies but IgM anti-VCA antibodies typically disappear 3 months after the primary EBV infection.

C) CORRECT:

Lymph node biopsies in cases of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) can show Reed-Sternberg cells, which are CD15/30-positive, polynuclear giant cells that originate from B cells. Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for HL and confirm the diagnosis.

Past primary infection with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), i.e., infectious mononucleosis, is a risk factor for HL. The most common histological types of EBV-associated HL are mixed cellularity HL and lymphocyte-depleted HL, and the median time to the onset of EBV-associated HL is approx. 3 years after the primary infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Auer rods on a peripheral smear are characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML causes bone marrow failure, resulting in anemia and an increased risk of bleeding and infections. Although the fever in this patient could indicate an infection, he lacks pallor and petechiae. Additionally, lymphadenopathy is not a typical feature of AML, and Reed-Sternberg cells would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Extreme leukocytosis (> 500,000/μL) is typical in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), a disease that causes B symptoms. However, lymphadenopathy is not a typical initial finding in CML, and the patient does not have splenomegaly, another characteristic finding in CML. CML would also not cause Reed-Sternberg cells.

F) INCORRECT:

The presence of acid-fast bacilli in the sputum is consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). Active pulmonary TB can cause B symptoms, and the incidence of TB is high in Africa and Asia, where this patient frequently travels. However, the most important finding in active pulmonary TB would be a productive cough and dyspnea, and histopathology would show caseating granulomas. Reed-Sternberg cells would not be expected.
questions.hint: Regional nontender lymphadenopathy, B symptoms with a Pel-Ebstein fever pattern, and the lymph node biopsy finding of typical Reed-Sternberg cells on an inflammatory background indicate a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of multiple swellings in both axillae. She says they are generally painless but are sometimes painful on the weekends. She also has increased fatigue, recurring low-grade fever, and generalized pruritus. She does not smoke. She drinks five to six beers on the weekends. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple firm, nontender axillary lymph nodes. A lymph node biopsy shows multinucleated giant lymphocytes with prominent nucleoli that resemble eosinophilic inclusions. Which of the following additional findings would be the strongest predictor of a good prognosis in this patient?

choices.text: Mediastinal tumor occupying 45% of the chest width

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mediastinal tumor that occupies > 33% of the chest width (mediastinal bulky disease) is associated with a poor prognosis for patients with Hodgkin lymphoma. Initial presentation with a mediastinal mass most commonly occurs in children (up to 75% of cases). Mediastinal bulky disease may be asymptomatic. Alternatively, compression or invasion of neighboring structures may cause localizing symptoms such as cough, dyspnea, dysphagia, pleural and pericardial effusions, and, rarely, superior vena cava syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

A nonmediastinal tumor measuring ≥ 10 cm across (nonmediastinal bulky disease) is associated with a poor prognosis for patients with Hodgkin lymphoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated ESR (≥ 50 mm/hour in patients without B symptoms or ≥ 30 mm/hour in patients with B symptoms) is associated with a poor prognosis in patients with Hodgkin lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

A leukocyte count ≥ 15,000/mm3 is associated with a poor prognosis for patients with Hodgkin lymphoma. Leukocytosis is one of the unfavorable factors included in the international prognostic score (IPS), which is used to evaluate the prognosis for patients with advanced disease.

E) CORRECT:

Lymphocyte-rich classical Hodgkin lymphoma (∼ 5% of cases of classical Hodgkin lymphoma) has the best prognosis of all types of classical Hodgkin lymphoma. Nodular lymphocyte-predominant HL (NLPHL) (∼ 5% of all cases of Hodgkin lymphoma), a type of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, has a similar prognosis but relapses more frequently.

In contrast, lymphocyte-depleted HL (LDHL) is a very rare (< 1%) but aggressive type of HL that is associated with a poor prognosis. Other unfavorable features include male sex, age > 45 years, stage IV disease, involvement of three or more lymph node areas, hemoglobin concentration < 10.5 g/dl, and albumin concentration < 4 g/dL.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of cyclical fever, pruritus, and axillary lymphadenopathy that become painful upon alcohol intake is suspicious for Hodgkin lymphoma. Biopsy findings consistent with Reed-Sternberg cells confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and multiple painless swellings on his neck and axilla. He reports that his swellings become painful after he drinks alcohol. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy specimen shows giant binucleate cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of regional contiguous lymphadenopathy, alcohol-induced pain in the lymph nodes, and B symptoms should raise concern for Hodgkin lymphoma. This patient's age further supports the diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma, which has a bimodal age distribution, with the highest prevalence in the 3rd and 6th–8th decades of life. Lymph node biopsy findings can show Reed-Sternberg cells, which are CD15/30-positive, polynuclear giant cells that originate from B cells. Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma and would confirm the diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults. Although lymphadenopathy and B symptoms are frequently seen in DLBCL, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis can manifest with B symptoms and lymphadenopathy. However, other hallmarks of pulmonary tuberculosis, such as a history of cough or hemoptysis, are not seen in this patient. Moreover, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Adult T-cell lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that can manifest with B symptoms and lymphadenopathy. However, this patient does not have other features of adult T-cell lymphoma, such as cutaneous lesions, bone pain (due to lytic bone lesions), and signs of hypercalcemia. Moreover, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) is the most common form of childhood leukemia and typically manifests with B symptoms and lymphadenopathy. However, unlike in this patient, symptoms of pancytopenia (e.g., weakness, pallor, or easy bruising) are usually seen. Moreover, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Acute retroviral syndrome is the classic manifestation of new-onset HIV infection. It manifests with a variety of symptoms, including fever, fatigue, rash, and lymphadenopathy, some of which are seen in this patient. However, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.
questions.hint: The giant cells seen on biopsy are likely to be positive for CD15 and CD30.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for episodic fever, recurrent night sweats, and a 6-kg (14.2-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. He reports that the fever lasts for 7 to 10 days, then subsides completely for about a week before returning again. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows nontender cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral mediastinal masses. Resection of a cervical lymph node is performed. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Further histopathological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Cells staining positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase
Cells staining positive for CD15 and CD30

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cells staining positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase are seen in hairy cell leukemia. HCL can manifest with B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, lymphadenopathy is uncommon in HCL, and this patient does not have other characteristic features of this condition (e.g., eponymous hairy cells, symptomatic cytopenia, and massive splenomegaly).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear sample (H&E stain)

A typical hairy cell is visible on the right side of the image. It is significantly bigger than a normal lymphocyte and its membrane has hairy projections (e.g., arrowheads). There is abundant cytoplasm and the nucleus (green overlay) is displaced to one side.

The presence of hairy cells in peripheral blood smears is characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) CORRECT:

The lymph node biopsy of this patient with Hodgkin lymphoma shows Reed-Sternberg cells, which stain positive for CD15 and CD30. These large cells have two nuclei, or at least a bilobed nucleus, and prominent nucleoli surrounded by pale halos (owl-eye appearance), as seen in the biopsy specimen here. They are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma and confirm the diagnosis. Other histological findings in Hodgkin lymphoma include granuloma formation and an inflammatory background that contains the following cell types in varying numbers: lymphocytes, eosinophils, neutrophils, macrophages/histiocytes, plasma cells, and fibroblasts.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

Cells with a BCR-ABL rearrangement are a characteristic finding of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). CML can manifest with B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, lymphadenopathy would not be expected. Furthermore, this patient does not have other common features of CML, such as basophilia, extreme leukocytosis, or a peripheral blood smear showing mid-stage progenitor cells (e.g., promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

A typical finding in chronic myelogenous leukemia is marked leukocytosis with a spectrum of neutrophils in different stages of maturation, usually not seen in the peripheral blood.

Seg: mature segmented neutrophils; St: stab cells/band cells; PM: promyelocytes; L: lymphocytes; P: platelets

D) INCORRECT:

Cells overexpressing Bcl-2 are seen in follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Either disease can manifest with painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, the pathological findings would differ from those seen here. Biopsy in follicular lymphoma would reveal densely packed lymphoid follicles with small cleaved cells, while biopsy in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma would typically show a diffuse growth pattern and large lymphocytes.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Cells with a t(8;14) chromosomal translocation are typically seen in Burkitt lymphoma, which can manifest with the painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms seen in this patient. However, this patient's Pel-Ebstein fever pattern would be atypical in Burkitt lymphoma. Furthermore, biopsy would typically show a starry sky pattern instead of the Reed-Sternberg cells found here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with cyclical fever (following a typical Pel-Ebstein pattern), cervical (and likely also mediastinal) lymphadenopathy, and B symptoms. His biopsy shows an inflammatory background featuring large cells that appear to be multinucleated and have prominent nucleoli (Reed-Sternberg cells). These features confirm the diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of night sweats, pruritus, and enlarging masses in his right axilla and supraclavicular area for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows painless, rubbery lymphadenopathy in the right axillary, supraclavicular, and submental regions. An excisional biopsy of an axillary node is performed. If present, which of the following features would be most concerning for a neoplastic process?

choices.text: Polyclonal proliferation of lymphocytes with a single nucleus
Abundant lymphocytes in a wide range of sizes and shapes in medullary cords
Preponderance of lymphocytes with a single immunoglobulin variable domain allele
Positive staining of the paracortex for cluster of differentiation 8
Diffuse mitotic activity in secondary follicles
Predominance of histiocytes in the medullary sinuses

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polyclonal proliferation of lymphocytes within reactive lymph nodes is a normal response to infection and is not indicative of a neoplastic process. Malignant cells often display atypical nuclei. However, a single, oval-shaped nucleus with an even distribution of chromatin is consistent with a healthy cell.

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytes and plasma cells normally occupy the medullary cords and multiply in response to stimulation such as infection. Depending on their stage of development, these cells are of different sizes and shapes, which is known as pleomorphism. This is a benign finding and not indicative of a neoplastic process.

C) CORRECT:

B lymphocytes with a single immunoglobulin variable domain allele indicate that these cells are monoclonal, i.e., they all arose from a single progenitor cell. The normal response to infection is a polyclonal proliferation of B lymphocytes with varying immunoglobulin alleles, whereas uncontrolled monoclonal proliferation from a single transformed cell occurs in lymphoid malignancies. T cells, in turn, rearrange their T-cell receptor genes during maturation. The preponderance of a single allele encoding the variable segment of the T-cell receptor is suggestive of monoclonal proliferation.

D) INCORRECT:

CD8, a surface protein found on cytotoxic T cells, is a co-receptor for the T-cell receptor and binds to MHC class I molecules expressed on antigen-presenting cells. Since the paracortex of lymph nodes is normally rich in T cells, CD8+ staining within the paracortex would be a normal finding and not indicative of a neoplastic process.
Image Description:

The parenchyma of the lymph node is divided into a B-cell zone (cortex), a T-cell zone (paracortex), and the marrow. The cortex contains primary and secondary lymph follicles with germinal centers, which allow affinity maturation of B cells. At the hilum (concave side), blood vessels enter and efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node. The entering artery and vein branch into a large capillary network. Special high endothelial venules in the paracortex allow for lymphocyte extravasation.

Afferent lymphatic vessels enter through the capsule at many points in the periphery and open into the subcapsular sinus. The cortical sinus runs from the cortex via the paracortex to the medullary sinus, which then drains into the efferent lymphatic vessel.

E) INCORRECT:

Secondary follicles are active lymphoid follicles with a dense mantle zone and a germinal center, in which B cells proliferate and mature in response to stimulation such as infection. Diffuse mitotic activity in secondary follicles is a benign finding and not indicative of a neoplastic process.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of a lymph node (H&E stain, 200x magnification)

The pale germinal center contains centroblasts and centrocytes. The darker mantle zone is composed of mature, naive B cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Sinus histiocytes are macrophages that reside in the medulla of lymph nodes. They are a normal finding and do not indicate a neoplastic process.
questions.hint: Primary neoplasms of the lymph nodes involve uncontrolled proliferation of a single transformed immune cell that normally resides there.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a progressively growing mass in his axilla. During this period, he has had night sweats, recurrent episodes of low-grade fever lasting for 7 to 10 days, and an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss. His only medication is a multivitamin. Physical examination shows nontender, right axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. His serum calcium concentration is 15.1 mg/dL and parathyroid hormone (PTH) concentration is 2 pg/mL. A lymph node biopsy shows granuloma formation and large CD15-positive, CD30-positive cells with bilobed nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's laboratory findings?

choices.text: Increased release of PTH by parathyroid chief cells
Induction of focal osteolysis by tumor cells
Secretion of γ-interferon by activated T-lymphocytes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive intake of dietary ergocalciferol (i.e., vitamin D) results in hypercalcemia and, via negative feedback mechanisms, suppressed PTH levels, which are both seen here. This patient, however, has Hodgkin lymphoma, making a different cause of hypercalcemia much more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Abnormally increased release of PTH by parathyroid chief cells is seen in primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT), which is most often due to a parathyroid adenoma. pHPT is one of the most common causes of hypercalcemia, secondary to PTH-mediated activation of osteoclasts that leads to increased bone resorption. Although this patient presents with hypercalcemia, his PTH levels are low; therefore, pHPT is very unlikely. Moreover, he does not present with typical features of the condition, such as nephrolithiasis, bone and joint pain, lack of appetite, nausea, and constipation.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteolytic bone metastases caused by tumor-induced focal osteolysis (secondary to the release of proteins that stimulate bone resorption, e.g., IL-6) account for approx. 20% of cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy. Such metastases are commonly seen in individuals with multiple myeloma as well as solid tumors (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, breast cancer). However, bone lesions in individuals with Hodgkin lymphoma are usually osteoblastic. Moreover, this patient does not have back or long bone pain to suggest bone involvement, making a different cause of hypercalcemia more likely.

D) CORRECT:

Hypercalcemia in individuals with Hodgkin lymphoma is a paraneoplastic symptom most commonly caused by increased extrarenal production of active vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D). Activated T-lymphocytes that surround Reed-Sternberg cells secrete γ-interferons, which increase the expression of 1α-hydroxylase in malignant lymphocytes and macrophages, leading to the excessive conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. High levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D induce intestinal resorption and renal reabsorption of calcium, resulting in hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia, in turn, suppresses the release of PTH, which is seen here. This mechanism of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D-induced hypercalcemia is also seen in chronic granulomatous diseases, such as sarcoidosis and tuberculosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by tumor cells is the underlying mechanism of humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM), a paraneoplastic syndrome that causes up to 80% of cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy. HHM would result in low levels of PTH since PTHrP is not detected by laboratory assays for PTH and hypercalcemia suppresses PTH production. However, HHM is most often associated with squamous cell carcinomas (lung, head, and neck) and renal, bladder, breast, or ovarian carcinomas. Hypercalcemia in individuals with Hodgkin lymphoma can, in very rare cases, be caused by PTHrP production, but the vast majority of such cases are due to a different pathomechanism.
questions.hint: The constitutional symptoms (e.g., night sweats, weight loss, characteristic Pel-Ebstein fever), painless lymphadenopathy, and biopsy findings indicate lymphoma. The presence of CD15/CD30 antigens and large cells with bilobed nuclei (Reed-Sternberg cells) confirms that this patient has Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a 2-month history of painless swellings on his neck. He also reports a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss during this period and increased fatigue. He has no history of previous illness. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His only medication is a multivitamin. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows several enlarged, rubbery, nontender, cervical lymph nodes on both sides of his neck, with the largest measuring 2 x 2 cm. An excisional cervical lymph node biopsy is performed. Histologic examination of the biopsy specimen shows giant, CD15+ and CD30+, binucleated cells with prominent nucleoli. In this patient's condition, which of the following is most likely to be associated with an unfavorable prognosis?

choices.text: High lactate dehydrogenase concentration on serum studies
Basophilia on a complete blood count

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A high lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentration on serum studies is associated with a poor prognosis in HL and many other malignancies (e.g., non-Hodgkin lymphoma, testicular cancer, AML). Tumors are thought to preferentially metabolize glucose to lactate even in an aerobic state (Warburg effect), which causes an increase in LDH concentration. Two processes further exacerbate the Warburg effect: increased tumor glycolysis (to sustain the high proliferation rate of tumor cells) and necrosis at the center of large tumors (likely due to limited blood and, consequently, oxygen and nutrient supply). Therefore, elevated LDH levels correlate with tumor burden.

Other factors that indicate a poor prognosis in HL include a high ESR, the involvement of ≥ 3 lymph node areas, large mediastinal tumor, bulky disease, factors included in the International Prognostic Score, extranodal involvement, the presence of B symptoms, and histological characteristics (e.g., lymphocyte-depleted subtype).

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytosis on lymph node biopsy indicates a good prognosis in HL. This finding is seen in lymphocyte-rich classic HL and nodular lymphocyte-predominant HL, the subtypes with the best prognoses, and in nodular sclerosing classical HL, the most common subtype.

C) INCORRECT:

The 9;22 chromosomal translocation (Philadelphia chromosome) is characteristic of CML. This translocation is also seen in adults and children with ALL (in ∼ 20–30% of adults and 2–3% of children affected by ALL) and in AML (in < 2% of patients), where it indicates an unfavorable prognosis. Although leukemia can manifest with B symptoms and, in the case of ALL, painless lymphadenopathy, this patient's lymph node biopsy confirms the diagnosis of HL. A 9;22 chromosomal translocation is not a typical finding in HL.

D) INCORRECT:

Young age at disease onset is associated with a good prognosis in HL. HL has a bimodal age distribution: adults aged 25–30 years most commonly develop nodular sclerosing HL, a histological subtype of classic HL that is associated with a favorable prognosis; adults aged 50–70 years often develop mixed-cellularity HL, which has a slightly worse prognosis. Age ≥ 45 years is included as a negative prognostic factor in the International Prognostic Score.

E) INCORRECT:

Basophilia is seen in myeloproliferative disorders, particularly chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Increasing basophilia is a sign of disease acceleration and can indicate an impending blast crisis. Although patients with CML are usually asymptomatic at diagnosis, some patients with this condition present with B symptoms. However, lymphadenopathy, as seen in this patient, is not a typical finding in CML. This patient has HL, and basophilia is not a prognostic marker in this condition.
questions.hint: Histologic examination of this patient's lymph node biopsy shows Reed-Sternberg cells, which are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue, recurrent night sweats, and a 5-kg (11-Ib) weight loss despite no change in appetite. She also reports multiple swellings on her neck and in both armpits, which she first noticed 1 month ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 56 kg (123 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows firm, nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A PET/CT scan shows multiple enlarged fluorodeoxyglucose-avid nodules at the neck, axillae, and abdominal aorta. An excisional axillary lymph node biopsy shows granuloma formation and large binucleate cells that are CD15/CD30-positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Combination chemotherapy with the ABVD regimen (adriamycin, bleomycin, vinblastine, dacarbazine) is the treatment of choice for patients with HL. According to the Lugano classification, this patient has stage III disease, which is defined by the involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm (i.e., neck, axillae, and abdominal aorta) without the involvement of extralymphatic organs. Radiation therapy is typically reserved for patients with limited-stage HL.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lymph node biopsy specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

A Reed–Sternberg cell (green overlay) can be seen in the center of the image. It is surrounded by numerous lymphocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads).

This histopathological appearance is characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Performing an MRI of the brain is indicated in patients with HL and neurologic findings that indicate involvement of the CNS (e.g., sensory disturbances, muscle weakness, headache, confusion). This patient has no signs or symptoms suggestive of CNS involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow aspiration is rarely required in the initial evaluation of patients with HL. A PET-CT scan can usually detect bone marrow involvement with high sensitivity, so an invasive procedure is not necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Cancer immunotherapy (e.g., with rituximab) is part of the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). This patient has Hodgkin lymphoma, for which there is no established immunotherapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Lymph node dissection is part of the surgical treatment of several types of malignancies (e.g., axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer, radical neck dissection for head and neck cancer). However, lymph node dissection is generally not recommended in patients with HL.
questions.hint: Weight loss, night sweats, and nontender lymphadenopathy in a young adult should raise concern for Hodgkin lymphoma (HL). The histopathologic findings of this patient's lymph node biopsy show Reed-Sternberg cells, which are pathognomonic for this condition.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of “swollen glands” in his neck for the past 2 to 3 weeks. He first noticed a swollen bump on the right side of his neck but then gradually found other lumps in his neck. He has had a dry cough with intermittent fevers of 38.3°C to 38.9°C. He has had trouble sleeping comfortably because of sweating and difficulty breathing, and he reports being more tired than usual.
He is completing a 10-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate today after testing negative for Epstein-Barr virus (negative titers).
On physical examination, he is sitting with a temperature of 38.0°C, a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 119/76 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. He weighs 62.4 kg, but at his well visit 5 months ago, he weighed 70 kg. He is awake and alert but pale. His ear-nose-throat examination is normal except for mild pharyngeal erythema.
He has diffuse anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy bilaterally that is confluent with the largest group of lymph nodes measuring 3 cm x 2 cm. There is no overlying erythema, and on palpation, the nodes are neither tender nor warm to the touch. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and he has no retractions or increased work of breathing. His abdominal examination reveals splenomegaly. The rest of the examination is normal.
A complete blood count is normal.
What is the most appropriate immediate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: CT of the chest with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An interferon gamma-release assay is used to assess for tuberculosis. Although tuberculous lymphadenitis is in the differential diagnosis for this patient, it is typically unilateral and thus less likely than lymphoma in this case.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation — gradually progressive adenopathy and splenomegaly along with systemic symptoms including fatigue and the “B” symptoms fever, night sweats, and weight loss — is concerning for lymphoma, especially since infection with Epstein-Barr virus has already been excluded.

Patients with lymphoma are at risk for developing a rapidly enlarging mediastinal mass with airway obstruction, which is a particular concern in this patient given his difficulty breathing when lying flat to sleep at night and his tachypnea on examination. Therefore, the most appropriate next step for this patient is a chest radiograph to urgently assess for an intrathoracic mass and evidence of airway obstruction. Depending on the findings, immediate interventions to secure the airway may be needed.

Eventually, this patient will need CT of the neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis, or integrated positron emission tomography and CT (PET-CT), as well as a biopsy of an accessible mass. However, CT and PET-CT would not constitute first-line imaging in a patient in whom malignant airway obstruction is suspected. A chest radiograph is the best and safest immediate choice in this case as it is faster, can be done with the patient sitting upright, and will guide immediate management.

Key learning point: A patient with likely lymphoma presenting with progressive cervical adenopathy should be urgently evaluated with a chest radiograph.

C) INCORRECT:

Most children with cat-scratch disease due to Bartonella henselae have localized adenopathy, and splenomegaly is rare. Although Bartonella infection is in the differential diagnosis for this patient, evaluating for a mediastinal mass should take precedence.

D) INCORRECT:

Peripheral blood flow cytometry may identify abnormal populations of cells and suggest a diagnosis, but normal flow cytometry results are not adequate to exclude a diagnosis of lymphoma, which requires excisional or core biopsy of affected lymph nodes. In some high-grade lymphomas, such as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, the cells are fragile and shear as they are processed through the flow cytometer, leading to negative flow panel results.

E) INCORRECT:

Eventually, this patient will need CT of the neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis, or integrated positron emission tomography and CT (PET-CT), as well as a biopsy of an accessible mass. However, CT and PET-CT would not constitute first-line imaging in a patient in whom malignant airway obstruction is suspected. A chest radiograph is the best and safest immediate choice in this case as it is faster, can be done with the patient sitting upright, and will guide immediate management.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and multiple painless swellings on his neck and axilla. He reports that his swellings become painful after he drinks alcohol. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy specimen shows giant binucleate cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of regional contiguous lymphadenopathy, alcohol-induced pain in the lymph nodes, and B symptoms should raise concern for Hodgkin lymphoma. This patient's age further supports the diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma, which has a bimodal age distribution, with the highest prevalence in the 3rd and 6th–8th decades of life. Lymph node biopsy findings can show Reed-Sternberg cells, which are CD15/30-positive, polynuclear giant cells that originate from B cells. Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma and would confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by painless lymphadenopathy, B symptoms, alcohol-induced lymph node pain, and Reed-Sternberg cells on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults. Although lymphadenopathy and B symptoms are frequently seen in DLBCL, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Adult T-cell lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that can manifest with B symptoms and lymphadenopathy. However, this patient does not have other features of adult T-cell lymphoma, such as cutaneous lesions, bone pain (due to lytic bone lesions), and signs of hypercalcemia. Moreover, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) is the most common form of childhood leukemia and typically manifests with B symptoms and lymphadenopathy. However, unlike in this patient, symptoms of pancytopenia (e.g., weakness, pallor, or easy bruising) are usually seen. Moreover, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute retroviral syndrome is the classic manifestation of new-onset HIV infection. It manifests with a variety of symptoms, including fever, fatigue, rash, and lymphadenopathy, some of which are seen in this patient. However, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.
questions.hint: The giant cells seen on biopsy are likely to be positive for CD15 and CD30.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of multiple swellings in both axillae. She reports that the swellings are generally painless but sometimes become painful on the weekends. She also describes increased fatigue, recurring low-grade fever, and generalized pruritus. She does not smoke and drinks five to six beers on the weekends. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. On examination, there are multiple firm, nontender axillary lymph nodes. Lymph node biopsy reveals multinucleated giant lymphocytes with prominent nucleoli resembling eosinophilic inclusions. Which one of the following additional findings would be the strongest predictor of a good prognosis in this patient?

choices.text: Mediastinal tumor occupying 45% of the chest width.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A nonmediastinal tumor measuring ≥ 10 cm across (nonmediastinal bulky disease) is associated with a poor prognosis for patients with Hodgkin lymphoma.

B) CORRECT:

Lymphocyte-rich classical Hodgkin lymphoma (∼ 5% of cases of classical Hodgkin lymphoma) has the best prognosis of all types of classical Hodgkin lymphoma. Nodular lymphocyte-predominant HL (NLPHL) (∼ 5% of all cases of Hodgkin lymphoma), a type of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, has a similar prognosis but relapses more frequently.

In contrast, lymphocyte-depleted HL (LDHL) is a very rare (< 1%) but aggressive type of HL that is associated with a poor prognosis. Other unfavorable features include male sex, age > 45 years, stage IV disease, involvement of three or more lymph node areas, hemoglobin concentration < 105 g/L, and albumin concentration < 40 g/L.

Key learning point: The lymphocyte-rich classical subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with the best prognosis among the classical types.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated ESR (≥ 50 mm/hour in patients without B symptoms or ≥ 30 mm/hour in patients with B symptoms) is associated with a poor prognosis in patients with Hodgkin lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

A mediastinal tumor that occupies > 33% of the chest width (mediastinal bulky disease) is associated with a poor prognosis for patients with Hodgkin lymphoma. Initial presentation with a mediastinal mass most commonly occurs in children (up to 75% of cases). Mediastinal bulky disease may be asymptomatic. Alternatively, compression or invasion of neighboring structures may cause localizing symptoms such as cough, dyspnea, dysphagia, pleural and pericardial effusions, and, rarely, superior vena cava syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

A leukocyte count ≥ 15 x 109/L is associated with a poor prognosis for patients with Hodgkin lymphoma. Leukocytosis is one of the unfavorable factors included in the international prognostic score (IPS), which is used to evaluate the prognosis for patients with advanced disease.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of cyclical fever, pruritus, and axillary lymphadenopathy that become painful upon alcohol intake is suspicious for Hodgkin lymphoma. Biopsy findings consistent with Reed-Sternberg cells confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and multiple painless swellings on his neck and axilla. He reports that the swellings become painful after consuming alcohol. On examination, there is nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy shows giant binucleate cells. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults. Although lymphadenopathy and B symptoms are frequently seen in DLBCL, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

Adult T-cell lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that can manifest with B symptoms and lymphadenopathy. However, this patient does not have other features of adult T-cell lymphoma, such as cutaneous lesions, bone pain (due to lytic bone lesions), and signs of hypercalcemia. Moreover, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

The combination of regional contiguous lymphadenopathy, alcohol-induced pain in the lymph nodes, and B symptoms should raise concern for Hodgkin lymphoma. Lymph node biopsy findings can show Reed-Sternberg cells, which are CD15/30-positive, polynuclear giant cells that originate from B cells. Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma and would confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by painless, contiguous lymphadenopathy, B symptoms, alcohol-induced lymph node pain, and Reed-Sternberg cells on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lymphatic tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

In the center of the image is a typical Reed-Sternberg cell (yellow outline) with two nuclei (blue overlay), each with a prominent cherry-red nucleolus (black arrowheads). This creates the characteristic owl's-eye appearance of Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, numerous lymphocytes with basophilic nuclei (arrows) are visible.

Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute retroviral syndrome is the classic manifestation of new-onset HIV infection. However, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) is the most common form of childhood leukemia and typically manifests with B symptoms and lymphadenopathy. However, unlike in this patient, symptoms of pancytopenia (e.g., weakness, pallor, or easy bruising) are usually seen. Moreover, this patient's histopathologic findings and alcohol-induced pain would not be expected.
questions.hint: The giant cells seen on biopsy are likely to be positive for CD15 and CD30.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the ED with one month of fatigue, intermittent fevers, and drenching night sweats. She denies cough or sore throat and is uncertain if she's lost weight as she does not regular weigh herself. Examination shows several firm, non-tender, mobile lymph nodes along the right posterior cervical chain. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 10.4 g/dL, white blood cell count 8,600/mm3 with 12% eosinophils, platelets 310 × 109/mm3, sodium 138 mmol/L, potassium 4.1 mmol/L, creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, calcium 9.4 mg/dL, AST 22 U/L, ALT 25 U/L, ESR 75 mm/hr, and a peripheral smear showing normocytic red cells with no blasts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration of cervical lymph node

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — This patient’s B symptoms (fever, night sweats), painless cervical lymphadenopathy, mild normocytic anemia, eosinophilia, and elevated ESR are characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma. These are common initial findings before diagnosis is confirmed by excisional lymph node biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis often causes fever and cervical lymphadenopathy, but typically presents with pharyngitis, tender lymph nodes, and marked lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. This patient has no pharyngitis and normal total WBC count.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis can cause fever and night sweats, but usually presents with cough, weight loss, and pulmonary findings. Isolated cervical nodes and eosinophilia are not typical.

D) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis can cause lymphadenopathy and constitutional symptoms, but typically blood tests usually show hypercalcemia, not eosinophilia or anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute leukemia can cause fatigue and fevers, but typically presents with pancytopenia or blasts on the peripheral smear, which are not present here.
